ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: You will be taught some of the foundational grammar and vocabulary of Polish.
Polish listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills
Beginner Polish, with a focus on more advanced grammar.
This course pushed us further in Polish conversation and grammar. The knowledge is very practical for everyday speech and functioning.
I learned how to speak more fluently and learned more about the culture.
I learned how to hold conversations in polish with polish speaking people.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: All of the material is very approachable and handleable, and the class is not too stressful, however sometimes it could move more quickly and cover more material.
I liked learning in class and giving presentations about topics in Polish culture.

Professor Illakowicz is the central strength of this course. She is truly phenomenal and down to earth. Her extensive knowledge of Polish history and film helped us gain not only understanding of the language but also the culture more broadly.
Could be more clear on test and quiz dates, but overall she does a good job in engaging the students.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The covid practices were good - nothing in particular needs to be improved.
No suggestions.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. The course content is engaging and the workload is not overwhelming. Whenever I meet a first-year student, I tell them to take Polish in hopes that they enjoy the course as much as I do.
Yes, if you are interested in Polish culture and language, or slavic studies in general, you will enjoy this course and learn a lot.
yes
Absolutely, Polish is such a fun course and Professor Illakowicz is amazing.
I would absolutely tell others to take Polish. It was the best decision I have made during my degree.
Yes, it is a interesting language to learn about and I think it is a great culture.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
asynchronous biweekly exercises
None
